subject: Leadership
title: Corporate Social Responsibility
description: A micro-lesson that makes Corporate Social Responsibility usable.

hook.text: Should companies just make money, or do they owe something to society? This debate shapes modern leadership.

buildup.text: Friedman said business has one duty: profit. Carroll said four: economic, legal, ethical, and philanthropic.

discovery.text: Carroll's CSR pyramid: be profitable, obey the law, be ethical, and be a good citizen. Each layer builds on the last.

twist.text: CSR becomes greenwashing when it's marketing, not substance. People see through performative good deeds quickly.

climax.text: Integrate responsibility into strategy, not PR. Measure social impact alongside financial returns. Be genuine.

punchline.text: Real responsibility isn't a campaign. It's a commitment.

quiz.question: What are the four levels of Carroll's CSR pyramid?
